reviewText:
I'm in your base, killen your dudes! This is a very simple and shallow tower defense game with a cartoon look and characters that look straight out of Team Fortress 2. For those that don't know, it has no affiliation with TF2. The game is basically a wide open empty map. You start with a certain amount of cash to buy your towers. You can place these towers anywhere, well almost anywhere. The enemies don't attack, they just run from their starting gate or gates all the way to your base. The game says your base, by base, I assume they mean your gate, because you don't see a base. These are basically open courtyards. If enough enemies get into your base, you'll lose the game. The limit is 20. Each game has at least 100 waves of enemies, so in 30 minutes you can get through 60 or so waves. Its very easy, it just takes a long time to make it through, but luckily when you quit it saves the game.

You're tasked with arranging these towers, making walls of towers, and making a winding path for enemies to follow. Basically make a maze of towers. Can you plug a gap and make an unsolvable puzzle? Nope. The enemies will plod through from left to right. If something blocks their way, they'll path around it, but not intelligently. They'll chose a path that can end up having more of your towers. There is a wide variety of enemies, standard soldiers that look like TF2's soldier character, a heavier character, that looks like TF2's heavy, they'll eventually get jeeps, motorcycles, tanks, helicopters and giant robots. What do they all do? Just walk. Again they don't attack you. The helicopters and planes will at least fly over your towers in a straight line headed for your gates. Your job is to destroy them before they enter your gate. Since every map is just an open courtyard, you can just make the same maze over and over again.

Now that we've covered the enemies, let's talk about the towers, there are a few types of towers based on what mode you're on. Classic mode has only 4 towers on every map. Extended adn endless mode have 6 towers. Gun towers with short range, goo towers, that have a longer range, but will shoot goo to temporarily slow enemies down. Next up there are long range missiles, which are great to have. For the fourth tower in classic mode, there is some sort of electro tower. You don't unlock any new ones. In extended and endless modes, there are flame towers and minimum / maximum ranged giant bomb spitters that are pretty expensive. You can upgrade each and every tower by right clicking it and selecting to upgrade it for a price. Do you want to know which towers do the most damage? The stats are in the help menu item, but they should be hover items that just appear when you go to select which tower you'd like to place. The tower guns turn, but the electro towers don't turn and you'll pay extra for it. You can hit the space bar to pause the game to plop down towers, but there are only two speeds, normal and fast.

The big issue that I have with this game is that its dull. There are far better and deeper tower defense games out there. This game throws 100 waves of enemies at you. It shows you a list of what enemies are coming next and where.... which is good, if I didn't have to click on it to open it up each time I wanted to see the list. Other wave based tower defense games simply have a list of what's next, like how Tetris would show you what block is next. Then the fact that each level / map is 100 waves. That's just far far too many. The game gets dull and boring long before you're done with 100 waves. If you beat 50 waves, then you unlock new maps. But really, the maps are all the same, entrances and an exit. The only difference is how it looks. If you get past 100 waves then it unlocks new modes for the map. The modes are painfully the same, just longer! After 90 waves I didn't even have to touch the keyboard anymore. I just watched the game play itself. There are also three difficulties for each mode if you dare.

When you die or beat a map, it lets you enter a high score with leader boards for your friends and all of Steam. The sad part is the score system is flawed. When you defeat an enemy, you get X amount of points, so if you have a perfect game where you kill everything.... you'll get the same score. It should have been time based. Kill an enemy quickly, get more points. Another problem that I have with the game is the fact to move the map around to see everything, you need to click and drag, but for the most part maps are the size of one screen, so you don't even really need to move the map, except for when a helicopter gets past you.

A lot of people on the forum complain about mouse lag, but really I don't notice it that much, other than in the menu, but its a game breaker for some. Another headache of this game is when you lose, you need to exit out of the level, then play it again, select the level and wait for it to load. A restart button after losing would have been appreciated.

Maybe this is a great mobile game, but for PC and Steam, there are better tower defense games out there. This one is just forcefully long, boring and offers no depth or variety, but at least there are nearly 100 achievements. You can tell how dull the game is when you look at the achievements, there are 85+ easy achievements that only 15% of people have unlocked. Go buy Field Runners 2.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of Tower Defence Genre, this game is only ok.
There's only a few towers and upgrades, but there are modes and three difficulties for each, along with several levels.

The AI isn't as good at TD as those in Warcraft III but it's addictive and fun for one evening.

You will be done with the game in just some hours. It's a nice game, but it would be better if it's longer and a better graphic would be good (it is an android game first).


Its a pretty good game to get in a bundle (with android-version!) or in a very very cheap steam sale.

If you want a good strategy TD, get Defense Grid: The Awakening or other TD-games.

reviewText: Fieldrunners offers fast-paced tower defence action where you pit a lot of towers against large hordes of enemies. It accomplishes the important aspect of a tower defence game decently - addictiveness. However as a downside it can wear off quite quick too, as the gameplay doesn't evolve at all, there aren't much different enemies and you possess the same towers all the time.\n\nIn fact, while the game is definitely not the worst that tower defence genre offers, it's place is better suited on mobile devices - play in small doses, with touch controls. Along with the small resolution and mouse lag issues, I would not recommend this game bought on computer, unless you really want it that way.

reviewText:

Fieldrunners does well at respecting the player's time and ability. There is no tutorial to suffer though, there's no two hours of tedious intro levels" to endure; you click "start game" and you better be prepared to play. Playing through on medium difficulty will provide the player with a respectable challenge.

Fieldrunners is a bit simplistic and if you are expecting an experience like Defense Grid you will be disappointed
date: however if you generally enjoy tower defense games you will likely enjoy Fieldrunners\n\nScore: 7/10"

reviewText:
Fieldrunners was a great iOS tower defense game (although probably the difficulty could use tweaking on some of the later maps), but it's hard to recommend the Steam version for the following reasons:
1. The price was always ridiculed on iOS, especially when the devs refused to ever bring it down, even during holiday sales, despite the fact the extra maps were actually at one point DLC that had to be purchased.  Even including the DLC levels, $10 seems a bit off for a bare-bones PC version that doesn't function properly (more on that later) and has been a mega-success for going on 4 years or so now.   This barely rose to the $10 level on iOS, and it's not remotely a $10 on PC in this condition.
2. The Steam version has a horrendous bug/glitch that the developers have yet to fix where mouse input becomes severely lagged after the second time you play it.  In other words, the first time you play it's fine, but after that the game is unplayable with virtually any form of mouse.  Touchpads on laptops tend to work, but some bizarre problem with the port causes serious issues with mice.  As of my writing this, this is not fixed.  The glitch does not seem to effect everyone, but it effects enough people that it's unfortunate it is not mentioned in the game description.

Fieldrunners is a great, basic tower defense game, but this port is really shoddy and the shoulder shrugging response on fixing the bugs frankly makes me regret ever supporting these devs back before they made their fortunes on the Fieldrunners IP.

reviewText: Fun tower defense with ground and air units, but sometimes doesn't feel fair - to you or the mobs. Its easy to build a map that makes a loop, and swapping two towers makes ground units stop and turn around to save them from exiting the level. Air units move quickly from entrance to exit, and some you have to build your maps with them in mind so you can stack air defense towers along their path. Also gives no starting resources so you have to build like a tower per round and slowly build up to make the starting maze.
Great game, highly recommended!

simples, e HARD .

I grabbed this game on sale for a dollar. After playing it for a while, I say it's worth it.

It's a simple tower defense game. Build your towers, upgrade your defenses and make sure the enemys don't get through.

Simple right? In a way, no. The game gets very difficult (at least for me) up to a certain point. Your game might start with some really strong guys running towards your base when you only have a couple of towers that don't do that much damage. Yet this usually depends on the difficulty you decide to play it on. The levels also look pretty nice too. Sometimes you might have to defend only one side and sometimes you have to defend 4 corners of the map. The game is mainly in 2D (Except the enemys) but looks quite nice. Each level feels different from the other one. One level you defend on a field, or you defend inside a large factory.

The design of the enemys are interesting. I like the design of the characters. They remind me of the Soldier and the Heavy from Team Fortress 2. Sometimes I don't take the game seriously because I keep thinking a bunch of Heavys are trying to destroy my base.

Overall, I give the game a 7/10 Mainly because I am not a big fan of tower defense games, but if you like tower defense games, then you might like it better than I do.

They also have a mobile version of this game for the IOS and Android last time I checked.

not $5 worth of fun, but its not bad
